Laundry was a joke, for underwear or socks it was around HK$60-70 a piece. Dry clean or hand wash were virtually the same price, extra for pressing (you can buy new ones for less). Internet did not come with the room price, and also over priced! Free internet only available in the lobby and you can take it to your room after connecting for 3 hours, sometimes less. The daily room cleaning wasn't top notch. I had spilled some of my silver eyeshadow on the sink and it stayed there around some of the sink joints. I had asked to have our sheets changed as it had been 3 days (they try to use a 3 day environmental policy - though you can request to have your sheets changed everyday if you like) The sheets looked changed, but at closer view they didn't get changed, so I called to make sure they get changed next room cleaning (was exhausted to have someone come in right away) Next day we arrive to our room after cleaning and find the same sheets, and clean ones on the lounge chair. I called and asked if they expected us to change the sheets? I asked for someone to correct this, we left for dinner and upon return the clean sheets on the lounge were taken, but the same old sheets! I called and so to not loose face said there was a misunderstanding and to have the sheets changed. They finally did it, but it made me wonder if it was being done on purpose. One day our room wasn't made up at all, even after calling and pushing the 'make room button'. I guess these things can happen if you stay for 2 weeks. Also all my amenities were being replenished except for hair conditioner. During turn down service I mentioned it to one of the girls, and she kindly and promptly returned with 2 big size conditioner bottles. Concierge desk was very helpful and extra things and places to go around Hong Kong. The location was a bit on the side, but really not a problem. One MTR station from central. Taxis are cheap in HK and if you go through the mall and take the exit by the skating rink, you'll find yourself on Austin Road and once done, it will be easy forever. We would walk to the Star Ferry and Temple street easily, but I am used to walking living in Paris. Enjoyed the exercise. Felt stupid taking taxis to some of these places in the first place (especially to temple street market) Got sick from seafood last day and got a late check-out. A hotel doctor cost was HK$1200, not including drugs, but an alternative was mentioned to me, which was the medical clinic in the elements shopping mall. Got treated with a shot and drugs all for just HK$250. So there you have it. I miss the shower, the bed and bliss amenities. Don't regret my stay. The staff were nice and helpful when you saw them. Great for young couples or design freaks. But I think I will stay at the pricier Hyatt, JW or Intercontinental next time.

Reviews.Title: “not the real hong kong experience”
Reviews.Author: spoilednomad
Reviews.Content: Stayed there for a weekend end of Feb. 09. Have traveled to HK for 20 years. I would NOT recommend this hotel if this is your first trip to Hong Kong. The location is not great. Too far to walk to a star ferry pier, so you need a taxi each time. Plus, you don´t feel the vibe of Hong Kong in this newly developed shopping mall in West Kowloon. They advertised a "fabulous room" with a harbour view on the net, but what I got was a PARTIAL HARBOUR VIEW. I felt cheated. The view was mostly ugly appartment blocks, and then, in between two of them, there was a glimpse of Victoria Harbour and the skyline of Central (and that only after upgrading to a different room category). Of course, it is a hip boutique hotel, and if you deeply care about the design of the hangar in your closet, this hotel is for you. Otherwise, try other hotels which are in the midth of things (like the Lankwaifang Hotel, not to be confused with the LKF Hotel) or which have a REAL harbour view, like the good old Intercontinental or the Conrad (upper floors).

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding Service! Gorgeous Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: HotMama168
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 2 nights at W Hotel this week. IT WAS SUCH A GREAT EXPERIENCE! I emailed them previously and gave them a long list of things I needed for my baby -- baby bathtub, crib, bottle sterilizer, baby food warmer, volt regulator (for my breastpump which was 110v), connecting rooms, etc. And they said they will take care of all of it... and they did. Check in was a breeze thanks to Tim at the Front Office. When we got to our COOL CORNER ROOM connected to a Spectacular Room, we were amazed. Everything we requested was arranged neatly in the room, waiting for us! And the baby things were brand new. They had an Avent Sterilizer and Mothercare Bottle/Food Warmer which looked unused! Perfect for us because we had the same brand at home and it was like we brought our own stuff there without the hassle! Rooms were gorgeous. The view was great. ICC building was blocking part of the view, but it was nice overall. It looked out unto HK side. If we were in the room during the Light Show, we would definitely see it. Decor was amazing. So chic and modern. Loved it. Toiletries were wonderful to use. We went over to FACESS in Ocean Terminal to buy more Bliss toiletries!!! I thought that the bathroom of the Spectacular Room was nicer than the Cool Corner Suite was nicer because the shower was in a separate area as compared to Cool Corner Suite which was in one bigger space... although the tub area in the Cool Corner Suite had a view.... so it made up for the joint space. I thought the extra space in the bedroom of the Cool Corner Room was worth it because the room had a little table where we had breakfast. And a couch we can lounge around on. Besides, with kids, the extra space was great. We used the IPod Dock for the kids' lullabies. There was only one cartoon channel, but it's understandable. I doubt that they have a lot of guests who watch cartoons! We had lots of shopping to do and didn't get to enjoy the pool But we visited it before checking out and it was so nice. We felt bad we were going home so soon and didn't get the chance to use it. LIKES... no, LOVES!!!: 1.Bed was uber comfortable with it's plush/pillow top. Sheets were PIMA COTTON 400threadct. So it was really nice to sleep on. It was so hard to wake up in the mornings because it was so nice to snuggle with the hubby and kids!! 2. Everything was so clean. I NEVER walk barefoot in hotels because I am scared of unsanitary carpets etc. But this was an exception. 3. Service is unbelievable. Whatever you ask for, they will go out of their way to help you. Everyone was so warm and friendly. They were smiling all the time and greeted us by name. Very well trained staff. Other hotels should learn from them! My son wanted to play with his Lightning Mcqueen remote control car. But we didn't have a screwdriver to open it to put batteries inside. They sent up a man from Engineering with a screwdriver. He not only lent us the screwdriver but actually help get it to work for my son! I tried to tip him after, but he wouldn't accept! DISLIKES 1. The location. It's on top of a high end mall. We were able to do some shopping at Elements, but not all our favorites... H&M didn't have kidswear. Zara was ok. No Toys R Us, Muji, Louis Vuitton, FACESS, etc. 2. Restaurants nearby are not that great. When in HK we only eat Chinese food. We love eating Peking Duck. But since we were with little kids, we didn't want to venture far from the hotel at night. So unfortunately, we had to stay in the mall, ate at Lei Garden on both nights we were there. Not fantastic. Just ok. 3. Didn't know where to get a HK breakfast with congee, noodles and the Chinese donut... Had to settle for the bakery in the mall. :( La Creation Gutten or something like that... Thanks KateTam for recommending this hotel. IT WAS SUCH A MEMORABLE EXPERIENCE FOR THE FAMILY! We're so glad we chose this hotel. Since I had a special needs baby and needed to be away from crowds, this hotel was perfect for us. Wish the mall had more stuff.... would love it if W Hotel was on top of Ocean Terminal/Harbour City! Haha!

Reviews.Title: “Very hip!”
Reviews.Author: relaxed_dude
Reviews.Content: Stayed here right after this new hotel opened. Very conveniently located connected to the mall and to the express train to the airport. The room was very modern, with very hip design. Pretty much everyting in the room can be remote controlled. We had a room with a view of the harbor. The staff was very firendly.

Reviews.Title: “Really nice - but almost to "trendy"”
Reviews.Author: 2FrequentTravellers
Reviews.Content: This hotel is one of the most well designed hotels, that we have ever stayed at and the overall experience is very good. The clientele is mainly younger rich people in their 30'ies wich likes to flash their expensive clothes. Pro: The room is extremely nice. The bed is wonderfull and al the electronics, build in tv's, surrond sound etc. is excellent. The rooftop pool is also very attractive. Con: The music in the lobby is too loud and the general atmosphere is almost too "fancy" with a lack of the exlucivity we expect from a hotel in this pricerange. The harbour view rooms do not face the Victorian Harbour, but a lot of docking ships. The bathroom is only seperated by the room by sliding dors - wich are note sound proof. So do not bring a shy date. The price is to high at normal prices, so go for a bargain. The roomrate changed from 3600 HKD to 1800 HKD during our stay, but the hotel did not reimburse us, so we had to check out and check in again.

Reviews.Title: “First Class Experience”
Reviews.Author: TDLS
Reviews.Content: We stayed here in late January and enjoyed it immensely. We felt the highlights were the attentive and friendly staff combined with a super comfortable room. The location is excellent even though its not in the centre of Kowloon. Certainly, Elements shopping centre downstairs with its Kowloon subway stop makes it easy (There is also a great cheap and cheerful Japanese restaraunt worth checking out in Elements). The W also offers a free shuttle every 30 minutes which brings Star Ferry and Nathan Road into play. We were waiting downstairs for the shuttle one evening and there was a mix up. It left without us and without a moments hesistation a paid for taxi was organised to get us to our destination pronto. Much quicker than the shuttle would have taken! The staff are very good. Even though Breakfast is expensive its also extremely good. It makes for a pleasant change to so many breakfast buffets at 4 and 5 star hotels. I agree that the hotel can sometimes be too cool for its own good. We had to ring a couple of times to ask how to work things in the room. If you don't like this sort of thing then I wouldn't stay here. Alternatively, the W hotel has managed to do something that is becoming increasingly difficult and thats be a bit different. You walk into a Sheraton, Four Seasons, Sofitel and they are all lovely establishments but they rarely differentiate. I think W and Hong Kong is a great example, does things which are different and that can sometimes be very refreshing on a holiday.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, but lacking soul...”
Reviews.Author: Sasibabe
Reviews.Content: Boyfriend and I stayed at the W HK for 2 nights on our way back from NZ to London in early Jan 09. I must admit that I have quite a penchant for boutique or funky hotels, and was looking forward to checking this place out... I had been torn between this and Langham Place in Mongkok because of the brilliant LP TA reviews, and I’m not convinced I chose wisely, for the money anyhow. Don’t get me wrong, this IS a nice hotel, the staff there are young, energetic, really lovely, especially the boys down on the door, very helpful and friendly. It’s uber-cool, cutting edge design from the kinetic floors in the elevators, the huge video screen behind reception ( mind you, if I worked on reception for too long, I’d be wanting compensation for my burnt out retinas) to the bathroom sink, and minibar. The clever one-touch mood lighting controls by the bed are great from a tech-spec point of view, though a bit annoying if you just want to turn the lights out and sleep. Having the airport express station directly below you is a bonus, and if you’re someone in need of yet another Prafengu (Prada Fendi Gucci) mall, in Elements, then this is the place for you. Bathroom is great, (yes, coz we all need a TV in the bath), the shower sublime, although I’m not sure about the shared sliding door for the loo and the shower cubicle..i.e. if you’ve got the door shut on the loo, then the shower area is open. But on returning to the hotel after a day hanging out in and exploring the gorgeous, perfectly dog-eared, sensual delight that is the heart of Kowloon, I felt like: what am I doing here? The W just seemed a bit sterile....too clever..too designed. I booked directly via the hotel website, a ‘Spectacular’ room (3515, about £170 a night during the soft opening) facing towards HK Island, but of course, what they don’t mention on their website is the HUGE skyscraper right in your face as you search for that mythical, evocative view of the Island. Still, you can get a wonderful view on the Star Ferry, which partly makes up for what you don’t get from the hotel room. We DID enjoy the bar, although it is another full-on, hyper-hip design confection that will look outdated within 5 years. BUT in its favour, there was a fantastic female bartender with cropped blond hair, who made excellent martinis (fanciful fruit ones, but also a great hand at the traditional one too). We both travel with laptops and thought it a bit odd, not to mention out and out mercenary, to have free wi-fi in the lobby, but to charge you for 24 hour use if you connect in the room . Maybe you can connect down there, and then bring your laptop up to your room, but it niggled us slightly. These days, wi-fi in a 5-star hotel should be a given. Perhaps I’ve just overdone the boutique/funky/hip hotel thing recently, but looking back now I think I’d rather stay in somewhere less funky and tech-savvy over in Tsim Cha Tsui and with a bit more Chinese or Asian soul and character . But if I was planning on entertaining my music/media/ fashion friends, or clients who’d appreciated the clubby vibe of the W, then sure, spend the money and enjoy. . It was without a doubt COOL, but it wasn’t a particularly romantic place or full of character... I think that’s my main gripe, but I can’t fault this place for service or presentation. Next time in HK, I’ll happily go there for a drink, but wouldn’t make it my base.

Reviews.Title: “Really great!”
Reviews.Author: k01lk
Reviews.Content: I arrived in the evening of January 25th, without expecting a lot from the place where I had to stay for 3 nights. However, from check-in to check-out, this place offers a series of very pleasant surprises where details make the difference. The most demanding guest will be pleased by the great service, the trendy atmosphere, the fantastic room and its amenities... In addition I had the chance to see (but not stay, unfortunately!) one of the suites: probably one of the most beautiful hotel accomodation I have ever seen...! The only negative point concerned the lift (very crowded and slow during my stay because of the opening ceremony). But in general a very excellent place where I will for sure stay again during my next trip to HK.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, But Typical W Form over Substance”
Reviews.Author: greeper
Reviews.Content: If only W Hotel spent a little less effort getting Wallpaper Magazine to notice them and more effort on giving people what they want, they'd be better off. Until then, it's more Poseur City, more Too Cool For You, more Be thankful you're allowed to stay somewhere so "hip" (and the quotation marks are there for a reason). For points [--](PLAT): W Hotel is too cool to give you SPG Platinum amenities, and are the only part of the Starwood chain that makes you pay for internet (18/day), has no lounge or free breakfast (or free anything). They do upgrade you, and we scored a corner room on 23, which means two elevator rides to get to your room. Look carefully and you'll find the elevator button, but only if you look real close. They wouldn't want to do anything uncool like just have a button. The big problem with the hotel is all the uber-tech BS in the room, like: you cant turn on/off one light; it's almost all or none; the annoying console next to your bed that controls the shades and lights is so bright you have to cover it up at night; the closet light is bright and literally cannot be turned off, so you have a nightlight whether you want it or not. The air handling system sucks every drop of moisture from the air and they give you two TINY bottles of water, but don't worry, there's a $10US bottle next to it. (Unlimited free waters in the gym). Upsides: The gym is pretty good, the locker rooms have amazing hot tubs with astonishing views. The pool is incredible. the shampoo etc is Bliss (there's a bliss spa on 72). There are 2 OK and way overpriced western restaurants (2 salads, 2 soups, 2 diet cokes and a drink = $100US). The locations is great, right above the MTR and Airport Express and adjacent to a mall with a Starbucks. The views are amazing if you can see through the smog. Overall, I will say it's a nice hotel, overdesigned, too precious and hip for its own good, with the W staff attitude that they are cooler than you (and they aren't). If you're SPG platinum, do the Meridien or Sheraton. Otherwise, it's a pretty good value and I would recommend.

Reviews.Title: “Unbeatable.....!”
Reviews.Author: miumiu0_0
Reviews.Content: Unbeatable hotel! Nice location, personalised room, great Chinese restaurant and stunning view. Really Luv the W sign everywhere throughout the hotel coz though it's a chain, it really gave me a feel of boutique hotel. I booked with www.macau.com . I guess they're running some partnerships, so I got a free cash voucher for my stay, then used the voucher straight away and extended my holiday to macau as well. I'll definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Stunning”
Reviews.Author: janethegooner
Reviews.Content: Beautiful hotel, super friendly and helpful staff. We stayed in a Fabulous Room which is a little more spacious but I would say all the rooms are definitely 5 star quality. There are buttons for every shade of light, curtains, blind etc which take a little while to figure but we loved it. Shame it was a little too cool to use the pool as it looked stunning. Couldn't recommend this place more and the location is perfect for the MTR direct from the airport to Kowloon station in about 15 minutes and just one stop over to HK Central. You can also check in with your airline at Kowloon station to save you lugging your cases right to the airport.

Reviews.Title: “Good but not great”
Reviews.Author: PA88
Reviews.Content: Despite the gushing reviews, my own opinion is that the W is a nice facility that overdoes the “coolness” factor at the expense of practicality with service that’s friendly but not yet up to top-level Hong Kong standards. The rooms occupy the 16th through 38th floors, with the lobby on the 6th floor and the ground floor having the drive-up lobby and access to the Elements shopping mall. There are two sets of elevators, one runs between the ground level and lobby and the other set between the lobby and the guest rooms. This means you have to use two elevators when leaving the hotel or returning. On the guest room floors, the elevator buttons are disguised in a bookcase wall decoration and hard to find. Two elevators also go up to the 76th floor where the pool is, and we found that sometimes those elevators would not stop at the guest room floors – so we ended up avoiding those elevators. As noted by others, check-in during peak afternoon hours was inefficient, with some waiting while the front desk checked available rooms. We rejected the first room offered as it had a faint reek of cigarette smoke even though it was on a no-smoking floor. The replacement room was not ready so we were told to return 2 hours later at 4pm. We did, but it took a 1/2 hour at the front desk to verify that our room was ready. When our bags did not arrive we had to call, after which they arrived promptly. The room, like everything in the hotel, has a dark grey color tone which is chic but cold. Some friends told us the room was 430 square feet, which seemed right. There are several annoying puzzles, such as how to use the TV (it’s hidden behind a sliding glass wall) and how to use the lights. You don’t have control over each individual light in the room – instead there are buttons that allow you to select “day,” “night” or “dream” – each of which is a lighting scheme. There are canned ceiling lights over the bed headboard which shine directly into your eyes when you lie down. These can be turned off by pressing a button next to the bed that’s labeled “Pillow” which we discovered by accident, thinking the button had something to do with puffing up the pillows or something. The lights generally fade in or out, so there’s a time delay between when you flip the switch and when something actually starts to happen. The “dream” setting turns out the main lights for sleeping and turns on footlights under the bedstands and the bathroom counter that are too dim to disturb sleeping but bright enough so you can navigate if you wake up in the middle of the night. This is a thoughtful and useful feature. The labeling of the light switches reflects the Hotel’s penchant for cute names that make it difficult to figure out what’s what. The hotel directory book in the room even has a translation guide (“wet” = pool, “fire” = ground floor bar, “bliss” = spa, etc.). The room has a floor lamp with separate fader switch. The window has sheer curtains and a thick blackout curtain, both of which are motorized. We had a “fabulous” room which I think means it had a harbor view. The view is not of the harbor towards Central, which is almost completely blocked by the new ICC tower, but is west towards Lantau Island. The pillow-topped beds and down pillows are extremely comfortable. Our room had 2 double beds which were somewhat cramped for 2 adults (definitely not queen-sized). Each bed has a small reading light on a wand, like you find in the business class section of airlines. There’s the usual wet bar items and hard liquor. The free in-room coffee/tea uses a boiler kettle and a stainless steel plunger-style infusion coffee maker. A packet of poor-quality coffee in a filter pouch suitable for a Mr. Coffee maker is supplied. Amazingly, when I called and asked for decaff, the hotel said they didn’t stock any and would have to go the grocery store to buy some at my expense. No thanks. Two small bottles of water are supplied gratis and restocked each day. Each morning the hotel delivers the South China Morning Post into a small bag that hangs outside the room door. The hotel, which has a motto of “Whatever, Whenever,” indicated other papers were available on request. I took them up on the offer and called to ask for both the Post and the Herald Tribune. After some confusion, they confirmed that both would be delivered but the next morning I only got the Post. I called to remind them that two papers were to be delivered and, after the same confusion about whether it was doable, delivered the Tribune. The same routine was repeated on the second morning when they delivered only the Post again. The bathroom is large with a large sink and two faucets. The bathroom can be closed off by two sliding walls that meet at a corner or kept open to the bedroom. A sliding frosted glass door closes off either the separate shower stall or the toilet stall. When one takes a shower, the toilet stall is left open. After the shower, sliding the door open results in water dripping off it into the toilet entry. Also, since there is no step-over into the shower, water leaks out onto the bathroom floor. The hotel left a rolled up a towel on the floor in front. In the shower you can use either a hand-held shower wand or a rain bath from holes in the ceiling. The spray is even and gentle, but if you are the kind that likes a powerful stream of spray, you’re out of luck. The bath also has a wand as well as a waterfall spout which is neat to watch but takes about 50% longer to fill the tub. The drain made a tremendous groaning noise unless the valve was set exactly right. There were 4 sets of heavy, luxury towels so we never had to call for extra towels, 2 thick terry-cloth robes and two sets of disposable slippers. The hotel provides both hard soap and liquid soaps. The liquid bath soap is labeled “Soapy Sap” and indeed smelled like tree sap, as did the shampoo and conditioner (labeled “sage”). My wife thought the scent was attractive. One thing I liked was that the small bottles were clearly labeled “shampoo” and “conditioner” in large letters – usually the print is so small you can’t read it. There’s a lighted make-up mirror in the bathroom which you cannot turn off separate from the bathroom lights and it can be bothersome glaring at you while you’re brushing your teeth. The electric plug is located around the side of the main mirror in an inconvenient location, and is the usual US/Euro 110V/220V combo. The bathroom counter has a fixed table lamp with a handy shelf to hold your small items. The bath has a small TV but it’s tricky to use the remote control. The TV has two sensors so unless you point exactly right, when you press the “on” button the sound will come on but not the video. We thought the TV was broken and the hotel had to send an engineer to explain the problem. The desk is well set-up with internet LAN ports, several electric outlets (Hong Kong 3-prong plug), and a desk lamp that is handy but located on the right side and therefore casts a shadow on the paper if you write right-handed. The wet bar snack tray has a universal electric plug adapter for your use that accommodates polarized 2-prong US plugs (where one prong is larger than the other). It does not accommodate US 3-prong plugs. There is a video port so, if you have the right cable, you can connect your laptop to the TV. There are also internet LAN ports next to the bed. The hotel charges HK$40/hour or HK$140/day for internet access. Free unsecure wireless access is available in the 6th floor bar area, but seemed to be limited to 3 hours. The telephone uses a touch screen and was somewhat confusing to decipher. Local calls are HK$5 for up to 30 minutes. The electronic in-room safe is wide and flat, perfect for laptops with room for other items. The large flat-panel TV has surround sound (speakers in the ceiling) and a powerful sub-woofer. Loud sounds like explosions in a movie made the room vibrate, but the room sound insulation appeared to be excellent. We never heard anything from adjacent rooms, the hallway or outside. There is a separate DVD player that can play US-formatted DVDs (region 1). For those who like to eat cheap, there’s not much available as there are only “nice” restaurants in the upscale Elements mall and building complex, which is isolated by undeveloped land and construction sites from the rest of Kowloon. However, the “360” grocery store in the mall has a pastry section, gelato bar and 3 food counters: one for Chinese and Japanese noodle and rice bowls (about HK$50), one for sandwiches, coffee and egg dishes (omlettes), and a grill for a variety of hot dogs and burgers (e.g., chili dogs, Hawaiian burgers). There’s also a small pastry shop in the mall near the hotel entrance that looks fancy but actually is cheaper than the grocery store. Both the bakery and 360 open at 8am. We ate in the mall at a Shanghai-style restaurant called Xia Mian Guan that was not cheap but pretty reasonably priced. It had excellent food and great xia long bao steamed dumplings. There’s usually a line outside but the turnover is fast. As mentioned in other reviews, the hotel is at the Kowloon station on the airport express railway and MTR (subway) Tung Chung line, with non-stop access to Hong Kong station on the Island. From HK station, it’s about a 7 minute walk through a new underground passageway to the MTR Central station and access to the MTR red and blue lines. There is no easy way to get to Tsim Sha Tsui from the hotel, except by taxi or free hotel shuttle that runs every half hour. Taxi access to Central is quick via the Western Tunnel which is adjacent to the hotel. Getting your check-in luggage from the hotel to the Kowloon airport express station under the mall is a bit problematic. The hotel said there was a dispute with the mall which doesn’t like hotel porters pulling luggage carts through the upscale mall. But if you check-in for your flight early, say 8 or 9am before the shops open at 10, then the hotel porters can help you take your luggage through the mall to the station. Another advantage of checking in early is that there are no lines. Otherwise, you can use a taxi for the 1-minute drive to the station entrance for HK$16. In order to use the station check-in, you must buy an airport express ticket for travel to the airport. If there are 3 or more in your party, ask the human attendant at the ticket counter for a group or family rate. We paid HK$190 (one-way) instead of HK$270 for the 3 of us. The discount is not available on the ticket machines. We found it convenient to check our luggage and get boarding passes for our United Airlines flight early, then have breakfast, walk around, freshen up in our room and check out of the hotel before taking the 20-minute train ride to the airport.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel; Awkward Vibe”
Reviews.Author: ModernDayNomad
Reviews.Content: The W Hong Kong is a mixed bag. While it's a very, very nice hotel, it's a property that appeals to a narrow demographic. You definitely have to think of yourself as a "Swinger" if you're going to stay at a W, and the W Hong Kong epitomizes the brand. W definitely appeals to a young clientele, and it's difficult to feel comfortable at a W if you don't fit the target audience. It does not pull off effortless luxury like the Inter-Continental or The Peninsula. The W is definitely trying (and in my opinion trying too hard) to be hip and fashionable. That said, the W Hong Kong is a beautiful hotel. The rooms must be some of the most luxurious in the city. Plush linens, soft lighting, plasma TVs, and slate bathrooms are a treat for the senses. (The shower was the best I've ever experienced). If you're looking for luxury, you can't go wrong. The lobby bar and restaurant (6th floor) were equally stunning, but neither offers a nice view. In fact, a 100+ storey high rise has been built between the hotel and Victoria Harbour, so the views are broken. The rooftop pool (76th floor) is stellar, however, and if you're in Hong Kong in the summer, the pool at the W must be one of the best in town. The W's location does leave something to be desired if you're in Hong Kong to see the sights. As others have noted, the hotel is a good 2 kms from the Tsim Sha Tsui and the Star Ferry Terminal. It's a taxi ride; not a walk. (Taxis are very, very cheap, however, and many drivers speak English). The hotel is also connected to the MTR, and Hong Kong Central Station is only one stop away, but it's not as convenient as a hotel in Hong Kong or in Tsim Sha Tsui. The hotel is also connected to the Elements Shopping Center. It's a massive mall with top-end designers and restaurants. Overall, I'd have to recommend the W Hong Kong. If I return, I'd probably stay at the Inter-Continental because it has the best location and the most stunning views in all of Hong Kong. Nonetheless, the W is a very nice hotel, and it's a safe bet if you're looking for modern, chic luxury.

Reviews.Title: “WOW. Initial check-in teething issues couldn't spoil the GREAT experience.”
Reviews.Author: britinnyc30
Reviews.Content: My buddy was meeting me there flying in from Toronto and was checking in before me. They messed up the rooms, gave him attitude yadda, yadda...you all know the drill.......I called from the departure lounge airport at Manila airport and spoke to the manager (and asked them to give me the corner harbour view room like I had booked- get this room type also!). 1.5 hours later I landed in HK and it was all sorted! Its a brand new hotel and I'm usually reticent to stay on the Kowloon side as I prefer being on HK Island. Well the fact that it is right above the airport express station in Kowloon was super convenient..you can be in the hotel 25 mins from leaving the airport. When you get off the train you can leave from 2 sides of the station...the wrong one will require a 20 minute walk thru the mall whereas taking the time to look properly will save you all those 20 mins. After living in Manhattan I was kind of put of the W brand by the trashy Times Square hotel which was 5 mins walk from my apartment, but all this is now firmly behind me! This hotel is pure cutting edge design and down to the smallest detail. The rooftop pool on the 70th floor is mind blowing- Philippe Starck meets South Beach Miami. The gym is also up there in the clouds and overlooks the harbour. Great showers/spa too and I loved all the water proof books for lounging in the spa pools. Rooms are large and comfy. The MTR is also downstairs and super convenient. AWESOME HOTEL. I will be back soon.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding hotel experience”
Reviews.Author: macx1981
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the W Hong Kong hotel with my wife for 3 nights including New Year´s Eve 2008/2009. The whole stay was an outstanding experience for us. For business purpose I´ve seen so many hotels in this price range already all over the world - but the W Hong Kong is really a very genial surprise! The hotel has a very young and fancy style - everything is extremly new and clean. Staff experience was over average. At 4 in the morning we asked the room service to bring ice to our room which arrived at our room less than 5 minutes later. Everyone was extremly helpful and smiling. The concierge ("Whatever/Whenever" service) organized us a table for New Year´s Eve dinner at the Top of the Sheration hotel (The Oyster and Wine bar) with an impressive view to Hong Kong Island on really short notice as we only arrived in Hong Kong at the 31th and didn´t make any reservations before we left Germany... The Whatever/Whenever service really cared for all our wishes and remembered our demands and hotel history during the whole stay - from check-in till check-out. The hotel has a top level pool area on the 76th floor with an impressive view to Hong Kong Island and Victoria Harbor. The location is not really central but you can easily go to the main sites in Kowloon with the free hotel bus shuttle and also using the MTR subway! Advise: Don´t take a taxi for your way from the airport to the hotel - buy a MTR tourist ticket. The price is way less than the taxi ride and includes 3 days free MTR subway usage. The MTR subway station is directly UNDER the hotel - so subway use is very convenient. The ride on MTR airport express from airport to the W hotel (KOWLOON station) takes you about 20 minutes only. Also Hong Kong taxis rides usually become a smelly experience... the MTR is clean and very comfortable.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: PanSW7
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the W Hong Kong for 6 nights overt he Christmas/new year period and was very satisfied. Excellent design, great views of Victoria Harbour and Hong Kong island and great location. The hotel is approximately 15 mins walk from the center of the Kowloon area (Tsim Tsa Tsui waterfront, the Star Ferry terminal, Peninsula Hotel, etc), so it feels just a tiny bit away from where the action is. However, it's directly above Kowloon rail/airport express/metro station. Kowloon is 1 stop from Hong Kong/Central station (accross the Victoria Harbour, on Hong Kong island), so it's actually very easy to pop to Hong Kong by metro, once you've done the Star Ferry thing at least once. The hotel itself is absolutely gorgeous, the hotel staff very friendly and cpable to help you with suggestions on what to see/do, dinner reservations and anything else you might need. Our room was gorgeous design-wise (and the bathroom was just amazing) but a little small, especially since we were 3 people. We had asked for a 3rd bed at the time of reservation (a few months beforehand) which was not there when we checked in, but the staff brought it in quite promptly. Still, it would have been nice if they had done this prior to our arrival and if they had given us a slightly larger room, considering there were 3 of us and paying a supplement on the price of the room for that reason. Free wireless internet access is available, but in a rather strange (and a little annoying) way. You have to log on on the lobby floor for 3h of access. Once you're on, you can take your laptop/PDA/iPhone up to your room and enjoy free access until your time is up. Then you need to go back to the lobby, log on again for another 3h of free access and so on. If you try to log on whilst in your room, there's a charge. Strange? Yes. But free wifi is free wifi, so that's that! The open air (heated) swimming pool and jacuzzi on the 76th floor is out of this world!!! Absolutely amazing!!!!!! I'd go back in a heartbeat!

Reviews.Title: “Very stylish, excellent location and dedicated staff”
Reviews.Author: globetrotter-ette
Reviews.Content: We spent two nights at the W hongkong in november 2008. In short, we loved the W hongkong and we certainly recommended to everyone visiting hongkong. The hotel is brandnew and very stylish looking a bit like a fusion of nightclub, art gallery and boutique hotel. The rooms are equipped with the latest electronic appliances from automatic light system, curtains and excellent TV/DVD and music system. Staff is excellent and treats you like you are their only guest and their future depends on you. On top of that, the spa is fabulous and has spectacural views. What we liked: # very stylish and at the same time creative decor of hotel and rooms. # fabulously friendly staff. Staff is very friendly and helpful and go the extra mile for making everything possible for you to have a great stay. The very knowledgeable concierge planned and organised a perfect 2 days sightseeing for us, incl. restaurant reservation. # great spa, gym and rooftop swimmingpool and jacuzzi with spectacular views over town. Everything is so clean, you don't even see a used towel in the towel bin. Plus we liked the free fruit and water in the spa, gym and on the rooftop swimmingpool. # great location. The hotel is attached to the kowloon station, which makes it really easy to access from the airport (airport express takes 21minutes), plus on the way out of hongkong you can checkin already at kawloon station (all big airlines have check in counters). Moreover there are a couple of great restaurants, bars and all the big brand retailers around. Plus they have a free minibus to take you to the ferry. What we didn't like: Can't really think of anything we didn't like. Apart maybe from the fact that prices for minibar, roomservice and food are very high (usd 10 for coffee).

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed it”
Reviews.Author: WirralChris
Reviews.Content: Can't add much to the other positive reveiws other than to say that, (although they're still in the soft opening phase so they should be switched on) the staff have really got it right. A good mixture of friendly and familiar. Fixtures and fittings appear exceptionally well made too - and it's a hotel that really looks and feels well designed. Generates a good vibe - as W hotels try to generally. Oh, spa wasn't bad either - like the Bliss products.

Reviews.Title: “Very interesting!”
Reviews.Author: bento2744
Reviews.Content: We spent 3 nights at the W pre-cruise first week of Oct. Arrived at the airport and was told that W was the easiest hotel to get to from the airport. We took the express train and got off at the Kowloon station. We were told the hotel was above the station, but because of poor signage, it was not easy to find. Many we questioned not familiar with the property, because it was very new. After asking for directions, we finally reached the front entrance, then had to take an elevator to the lobby. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Once we reached our room, our baggage was delivered timely. The hotel is very modern and high tech, we had to call the front desk for instructions to operate the lights and few other things. They have system you see in European countries, where you have to insert your room key into the slot located near the door for all electrical needs. The room has very clean styling with large screen TV, hidden behind sliding mirror. Our room did not have the full harbor view, but partial. The very best Harbor view is still the Intercontinental, that is the ultimate for views. The hotel does provide free shuttles to Star Ferry Terminal and other destinations close by. Lots of constructions going on around the hotel. I did not see too much activities in their restaurants, except there was a wedding taking place. We searched for local cuisine all around town. 3 days were enough for us to see most of Hong Kong, including side-trip to Lamma Island. Make certain you bring your swim wear, because their pool on the 76th floor is the highest pool in town. Both pool and jacuzzi are infinity style and the view from jacuzzi is simply beautiful. Hotel driver delivered us to our ship, the Regent Mariner, right on the dock. He was a perfect host to us, more so than others, we were very pleased with over-all service provided by the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “W stands for Wunderbar!”
Reviews.Author: EdmontonFritz
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 8 nights at the W in mid October and totally loved it. We really liked: 1. The staff - very friendly and helpful, much more so than your usual North American hotel. 2. The room - clean,new,modern, the 5.1 sound surround system and 42" flatscreen hidden behind the mirror, TV behind the glass in the bathtub,double sinks. We really really liked: 1. It's location above the Kowloon station and attached to the Elements mall, which meant that you are on the airport express line and the MTR that goes under the harbour to Central. 2. The large pool and hot tub on the 76th floor. We really really really liked the breakfast buffet in the kitchen every morning.

Reviews.Title: “Why, oh why!?”
Reviews.Author: Tyler_R
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the W in Hong Kong shortly after it opened. I was excited because i typically love W hotels - especially the new ones. I booked one of the FABULOUS rooms with the "full harbor view" and was disappointed to discover that you don't get the typical "million dollar view" you want in a Kowloon hotel (the view of downtown HK) but instead a view of a side of the harbor with a bunch of nasty cargo ships parked in it! :-( So sad, since the only reason to stay in Kowloon is for the view. In any case, yes - the hotel was fabulous and very W-like. But for the price being charged I would have expected a real view and I didn't get that and I was ultimately really unhappy about that. Fortunately, I changed to the HOTEL LKF for the rest of my stay in Hong Kong and it was FABULOUS! I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Willing and Able W”
Reviews.Author: tokyolady
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the W Hong Kong for 8 nights. First impression of the W was that it was futuristic(and I live in Tokyo). A little overwhelming at times. The TV is hidden behind a glass mirrror, the gadget on the desk is a kalidescope, and the phone...well, just dial '0' if you can't figure out the computer screen. Location rocks if you are a quality shopper: gucci, dianne von furstenburg and the lot live at elements shopping mall next door. Not to mention, a gourmet supermarket, cinema, and ice rink with a vast array of restaurants and a bookstore with an assortment of english literature. The staff are the cream of the crop..eager and always willing and able to lend a hand. I didn't try FIRE but the 6th floor restaurant was very good. Keep up the great work W hotel and I hope to see you again!!

Reviews.Title: “WOW Marvelous Modern W Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Mulholland
Reviews.Content: And I do mean WOW from the electric window shades to the above and beyond customer service. This is a very high tech modern hotel. The lighting designers deserves an A+. I WANT THE NAME OF THAT DESIGNER!!! The Spa was one of the nicest ones that I have seen. The jacuzzi has a great view of the city. The Room: Mine had a view of the harbor. Electric shades, big flat screen TV, Coffee Press (very cool), Shower with all the fun sprays. The tub didn't have jets (but I wasn't in a suite). The dining room is fun. In the kitchen is a nice table where you can eat and watch them cook. I had a table with a view. The bar area also has a nice view and they also had a yummy continential breakfast served there. (It's NOT all you can eat, they charge you for each item.) The staff was so kind and helpful. Big Tip: The Hotel is actually at the Elements Mall. This is key to understand since it is a new hotel. In the Elements Mall is the airport check-in. Yes, I know it sounds odd but it is a very convenient service which makes the hotel a great location. Therefore, take the MTR from the airport, it's faster and more comfortable then a taxi.

Reviews.Title: “Trying to be cool is NOT cool”
Reviews.Author: CHM1
Reviews.Content: Brand new and the first hotel to open in the area (with Ritz Carlton coming in in 2010), this latest luxury hotel is Hong Kong, is... well, trying to be cool. Located in the lower half of a 70-storey tower, rooms are designed well, with excellent bathrooms (cool sink, sliding doors, large tub, Bliss toiletries, rain shower), large HD LCDs (also nicely concealed behind a sliding mirror), and ok size rooms. Outdoor pool on the 76/F is not open yet, and the Bliss Spa below is in its final preparation. Actual lobby is still under construction. Views are ok. The "Million-dollar view" towards Central is completely blocked by the 101-storey skyscraper right in front of it. So the best harbour view is towards the west. The view towards the city on Kowloon side is more interesting. Everything in the room was an attempt to be "cool". Light controls just marked "Day", "Sleep", "Evening", iPod connectors, in-built surrounding sound system (that's awesome!). Although the room is equipped with blinds that block out all outside lights, these controls, be it the lights, emergency exit, telephone, all around the room actually light up the room much, which is a complete design failure. Didn't find staff to be especially helpful, as I was stuck outside the entrance because there was some hip party happening and they couldn't quite let me in... Everything is charged, and outrageously. Simple breakfast for 2 costs over $800. Can definitely find better value for money elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Great, great, great !!!”
Reviews.Author: luxmon
Reviews.Content: We had the wonderful chance of staying 2 nights in a corner room in the newly built W HKG. We have not been disappointed: * Overall impression: Great atmosphere, from the first moment you enter the ground floor (accessible from the road as well as from the Elements shopping Mall). * Lobby on 6th floor accessible through three crazy elevators with televisions on the floor. Typical W bar with loud music. * Rooms: Very nice and almost "too classical" for W standards ! As usual in HKG, beautiful views. * Bathroom: Exceptional, with floor to ceiling windows, bath, rain shower and television. * Main Restaurant: Probably the most fabulous breakfast concept I have ever seen: The buffet is located in a "real kitchen", making you feel at home. * Restaurant "Fire"(Gourmet restaurant): Only white, black and deep red tones. Chief is from NZ and is serving truly innovative and tasty food. * Wet zone: Gym with two personal trainers, spa with terrific views on Kowloon, swimming-pool (infinity) on 76th floor. Absolutely stunning! * Staff: we could not fault any single person in 48 hours. Young, helpful, friendly. Simply "W" with a lot of warmth. We wish all, especially the very friendly Ulysses, a great "grand opening" in September. Just carry on like this and the W will soon become one of the "Grand" hotels in HKG!

HotelInfo.Name: W Hong Kong
HotelInfo.Address: No.1 Austin Road West, Kowloon Station, Hong Kong, China
